moves.1. h3 e5: 1. ..... e5 - conventional development.  Charlotte's first move is not the best but it is playable.
moves.2. a3 d5: 2. .... d5 - after a second flank pawn move by Charlotte I decided to control the centre of the board.
moves.3. b3 Nf6: 3. .... Nf6 - after another pawn move from Charlotte I decided that I would develop my knight.
moves.4. Nf3: 4. Nf3 - at least Charlotte now knows without prompting that a knight moves in an l shape.
moves.4... Nc6 5. Nc3: 5. Nc3 - both sides bring out our remaining knights.
moves.5... a6: 5. ...... a6 - I am preparing d4 and hoping to swindle Charlotte into losing her knight!
moves.6. a4 d4 7. a5: 5. a5 - Charlotte does not notice that her knight on c3 is en prise and I now take full advantage.
moves.7... dxc3 8. dxc3: 8. dxc3 - naturally Charlotte gets a pawn back for the piece.  Now I decided to trade queens here as I am ahead on material.
moves.8... Qxd1+ 9. Kxd1 Bf5: 9. ..... Bf5 - after the queen trade I am planning to put Henry away on the queenside.
moves.10. Bd2: 10. Bd2 - Charlotte anticipates that she might be subject to castle fire along the d column, so she decided to develop her bishop.
moves.10... O-O-O 11. Rb1 Bc5: 11. ..... Bc5 - I could have played Nxa5 here but I decided to clear the decks.  At least two of Charlotte's pawns are now en prise.
moves.12. h4 Bxf2: 12. ..... Bxf2 - I take on f2 and I now have a dastardly plan which will unveil itself in the next few moves.
moves.13. h5 Ng4 14. c4 Ba7: 14. ..... Ba7 - an innocuous looking move but it involves a square clearance for my knight to come into f2 with check.
moves.15. c5: 15. c5?? - blocks the diagonal of Fou Lenoir but she overlooks the fork on f2.
moves.15... Nf2+ 16. Kc1 Nxh1 17. h6 gxh6: 17. ..... gxh6 - and now, Charlotte being the equivalent of a whole queen to the bad, now waves the white flag.  Better luck next time, Charlotte!

players: Charlotte Rowena Stevens (Unr) vs. Joanne Rowena Stevens (1200)
